data.title: Chest Pain Risk Stratification for ACS
data.content:
Chest Pain: Risk Stratifying for ACS

U.S. national average for missed cardiac ischemia = 2-4%

Missed AMI: Highest overall cost to insurers of all missed diagnoses in ED

Dilemma: "Low-risk" patients per risk factors and presentation may not be low-risk enough to d/c patient home. In contrast, not ALL low-risk patients need testing and admission.

Profile of the "missed AMI" patient

Younger age (< 55 years old) Women Nonwhite race Atypical symptoms Most common presenting sx: Dyspnea >> diaphoresis, nausea, or syncope Most common patient profile for having NO chest pain in ACS presentation:

  • Elderly
  • Female
  • Hypertension
  • DM
  • History of CHF

Global Registry of Coronary Events Failure to see signs of ischemia on initial EKG Failure to obtain EKG Physician inexperience Lower volume EDs

TIMI Risk Score for UA/Non-STEMI

Clinical variable Score
Age > 65 years +1
≥ 3 CAD risk factors
(FHx, HTN, DM, hyperchol, active smoker)		 +1
Known CAD (stenosis > 50%) +1
Aspirin use within last 7 days +1
Recent severe angina
( ≥ 2 anginal events within 24 hours)		 +1
Elevated cardiac markers +1
ST segment deviation > 0.5 mm +1

14-day "event rate":

  • 2 points - 8.3%
  • 3 points - 13.2%
  • 4 points - 19.9%
  • 5 points - 26.2%
  • 6-7 points - 40.9%

Beware: 30-day ischemic complication rate of TIMI score of 0 is still 1.7-2.1%.

  • Thus low-risk CP pts should have further outpatient diagnostic testing.
  • TIMI score best for risk stratifying high-risk (not low-risk) pts.

(Antman et al., JAMA, 2000)

Normal cardiac cath patient who presents with chest pain

(Burgiardini et al Arch Intern Med, 2006)

  • 7,656 patients
  • Looked at patients with normal or mild CAD (<50% stenosis) on cath.

Result: 1-year death or AMI found in 1.2% (normal cath) and 3.3% (mild CAD)

  • Normal cath alone should not completely r/o ACS on representation of CP.

References

  • Bugiardini R, Manfrini O, De Ferrari GM Unanswered questions for management of acute coronary syndrome: risk stratification of patients with minimal disease or normal findings on coronary angiography, Arch Intern Med. 2006 Jul 10; 166 (13): 1391-5
  • Jones, Slovis. Pitfalls in Evaluating the Low Risk Chest pain Patient. Emerg Med Clin North Am. 2010 Feb;28(1):183-201, ix. doi: 10.1016/j.emc.2009.10.002.
  • Antman E et. al. The TIMI risk score for unstable angina/non-ST elevation MI: A method for prognostication and therapeutic decision making. JAMA. 2000 Aug 16;284(7):835-42.
